## Background and Context

Innovation, Science and Economic Development (ISED) is seeking a solution to explore and demonstrate new quantum sensing protocols close to or beyond the Heisenberg limit. Circuit Quantum Electrodynamics (CQED) with superconducting qubits is the preferred platform for this challenge, where controlled-displacement operations enable researchers to test and search for novel quantum sensing protocols.

## Challenge Statement Summary

This challenge is issued under the Innovative Solutions Canada Program (ISC) Call for Proposals 003 (EN578-20ISC3). ISED is seeking a turn-key solution to single-mode resonator using superconducting qubits in a CQED architecture where arbitrary quantum states can be generated.

The proposed solution must:

1. Be able to implement a single-mode detector based on CQED in the 7-10 GHz bandwidth.
2. Provide a gate with process fidelity of 90% or higher to enable universal protocols for state preparation.
3. Be long-lived such that 10 gates can be applied within the decoherence time of the control subsystems.
4. Be turn-key with pre-defined and automated calibration of the single mode detector that enables non-specialist to operate.
5. Provide a programming framework and interface to control the device.
6. Provide access to 3 different coupling configurations for the single-mode sensor hardware.

## Funding and Timeline

The estimated contract value for Phase 1 is up to $150,000.00 CAD for up to 6 months, with an estimated 1-2 contracts to be awarded.
